revision.text:
{{Italic title}} '''''Heimkommen''''' (Homecoming) and the related [[hashtag]] '''#heimkommen''' is a German commercial video for the supermarket corporation [[Edeka]] that [[viral video|went viral]] in November and December 2015.
In the commercial, [[Arthur Nightingale]] plays a German grandfather faking his own death to reunite his family on Christmas.<ref name="Tagesspiegel" /><ref name="Welt" />
== Video == The 1:46-minute commercial shows a well-to-do grandfather receiving messages over the years from his successful children around the world, who call off family get-togethers at Christmas time. Each year he eats his Christmas dinner by himself. Eventually he fakes his own death, and his grieving children and grandchildren travel to his home, only to find him still alive. He tells them, "I had no other way to bring you together". After the family unites in a joyful Christmas dinner, the final shot shows the Edeka logo.<ref name=clip/>
[[Arthur Nightingale|Arthur Tulloch Nightingale]] plays the role of the grandfather<ref name="Tagesspiegel" >{{cite news |agency=[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|DPA]] |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/weltspiegel/werbung-vor-weihnachten-edeka-und-der-einsame-rentner/12658278.html |title=Edeka und der einsame Rentner [Edeka and the lonely retiree] |newspaper=[[Der Tagesspiegel]] |date= November 30, 2015 |language=German }} and Stella Stocker plays his daughter.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://abc7.com/family/home-for-christmas-grandfather-goes-to-extremes-in-german-ad/1106445/ |title=Grandfather Goes to Extremes to Bring Family Home for Christmas in German Ad |publisher=[[KABC-TV|ABC 7]] |location=Los Angeles |date=December 2, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.9news.com.au/national/2015/12/03/14/42/031215-9news-christmas-ad |title=German Supermarket's Christmas ad brings millions to tears |publisher=[[Nine News|9News]] |date=December 3, 2015}}</ref> The advertising agency is [[Jung von Matt]]. [[Alex Feil]] directed the clip, which was shot in [[Prague]] and [[Bangkok]].<ref name="Welt">{{cite web |url = https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/article149471535/So-wurde-der-Edeka-Spot-auf-Erfolg-optimiert.html|author = Kerstin Münstermann|hrsg = |title= So wurde der Edeka-Spot auf Erfolg optimiert [How the Edeka spot was optimized for success] |website = [[Die Welt]] |date= December 1, 2015 |archiv-url = |archiv-datum = |offline = |accessdate = December 17, 2015 |language=German}}</ref> Florian Lakenmacher of ''Supreme Music'' wrote the song "Dad" for it, which is sung by [[Neele Ternes]].<ref name="ternes">{{cite web |url = http://www.salsa-und-tango.de/dad-von-neele-ternes-song-der-edeka-werbung-als-download/69586/|title = "Dad" von Neele Ternes – Song der Edeka-Werbung als Download|website = Salsa-und-tango.de|archiv-url = |archiv-datum = |offline = |accessdate = December 20, 2015 |language=German }}</ref> The song reached number 43 on the German charts.<ref name="charts">{{cite web |url = https://www.offiziellecharts.de/titel-details-1504341|hrsg = |title = Offizielle Deutsche Charts [Official German Charts] |website = offiziellecharts.de |archiv-url = |archiv-datum = |offline = |accessdate = December 20, 2015 |language=German}}</ref>
== Viral phenomenon == Edeka published the commercial on [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]] on November 28, 2015. By December 2 it had received 300,000 likes and 500,000 shares on Facebook and over 20 million views on YouTube.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stern.de/familie/leben/edeka-werbung--weihnachten--heimkommen-zum-opa-inspiriert-facebook-user-6585010.html |title=Plötzlich wollen Weihnachten alle zu Opa [Suddenly everyone wants to go to Grandpa's for Christmas] |newspaper=[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]] |date=December 2, 2015 |language=German }}</ref> {{As of|2015|12|18}}, views on YouTube had passed 43 million.<ref name=clip>{{cite web |title=EDEKA Weihnachtsclip - #heimkommen [EDEKA Christmas clip - #heimkommen] |publisher=Edeka |website=YouTube |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V6-0kYhqoRo |accessdate=December 18, 2015 |language=German }} (with English subtitles)</ref>
== Reviews and reactions == British retail chains (compare [[John Lewis Christmas advert]]) often use emotional commercials for Christmas, but this had not been the custom in Germany.<ref>{{cite web |title = Culture: The Christmas commercials that turned into a smash hit |date=November 8, 2015 |url = http://www.dw.com/en/the-christmas-commercials-that-turned-into-a-smash-hit/a-18835081 |accessdate = December 21, 2015 |publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Business: German supermarket's Christmas ad goes viral |date=November 30, 2015 |url = http://www.dw.com/en/german-supermarkets-christmas-ad-goes-viral/a-18884504|accessdate = December 21, 2015 |publisher=Deutsche Welle }}</ref> #heimkommen led on a current chart of such ads with more than 33 million clicks after a week.<ref>{{cite web|title = German supermarket Edeka's Christmas ad beats John Lewis and Sainsbury's on YouTube |url = http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/article/1376221/german-supermarket-edekas-christmas-ad-beats-john-lewis-sainsburys-youtube|accessdate = December 21, 2015 |newspaper=Marketing Magazine UK |date=December 9, 2015|author = Shona Ghosh}}</ref> The video is a showcase for [[Integrated marketing communications]] on different channels.<ref>{{cite web|title = Jung von Matt gelingt Weihnachts-Sensation für Edeka [Jung von Matt Achieves Christmas Sensation for Edeka] |url = http://www.wuv.de/agenturen/jung_von_matt_gelingt_weihnachts_sensation_fuer_edeka |author=Frank Zimmer |accessdate = December 21, 2015 |newspaper=Werben und Verkaufen |language=German }}</ref>
Parodies have appeared including: a family angry about the deception killing their grandfather<ref>{{YouTube|id = ifg6SHfpMxE|title = Circus HalliGalli Weihnachtsclip – #heimkommen}}, December 14, 2015</ref><ref>{{cite news |author = Michael Hanfeld|title = Anti-Edeka-Werbespot 'Du perverser alter Mann' [Anti-Edeka Ad: 'You Perverse Old Man'] |newspaper = [[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]|date=December 15, 2015 |issn = 0174-4909|url = http://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/medien/joko-und-klaas-machen-edeka-werbung-zum-weihnachtsshowdown-13967436.html|accessdate = December 21, 2015 |language=German}}</ref> and a [[Deutsche Bahn]] image showing Arthur Nightingdale in a train [[dining car]] and the caption: ''Lieber Opa, warte nicht bis sie zu Dir kommen'' (Dear Grandpa, don't wait till they come to you).<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.facebook.com/dbbahn/photos/a.155291757840107.23113.152033178165965/953434851359123/?type=3|publisher=[[Facebook]] |title=Chronik-Fotos #124 |author=[[Deutsche Bahn|DB Bahn]] |archiv-datum = |offline = |date= December 2, 2015|accessdate= December 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title = #Heimkommen: So kümmert sich die Bahn um den Edeka-Opa [How the Railroad Deals With the Edeka Grandpa] |url = http://www.wuv.de/marketing/heimkommen_so_kuemmert_sich_die_bahn_um_den_edeka_opa|newspaper=Werben und Verkaufen |accessdate = December 21, 2015 |author = Ulrike App|date= December 3, 2015}}</ref> An Italian PR agency reworked the spot shortly after its release with an Italian background; in their version, the [[Grandfather|nonno]] expresses fears about his stock of [[Parmigiano-Reggiano|Parmesan]] cheese deteriorating.<ref>{{cite web|title = Il nonno si finge morto per Natale? Spunta la parodia italiana dello spot [Grandpa fakes his death for Christmas? Check out the Italian parody of the ad] |url = http://www.lastampa.it/2015/12/07/multimedia/societa/vi-ricordate-del-nonno-solo-a-natale-spunta-la-parodia-italiana-dello-spot-3BlEm3FDfExnCk7TOOr3mL/pagina.html|accessdate = December 22, 2015 |language=Italian |newspaper=[[La Stampa]] |date = December 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = 'Se non venite tutti, butto via la parmigiana'. La risposta di Casa Surace allo spot del nonno di Edeka ['If you don't all come, I'll throw out the parmesan': Casa Surace's answer to Edeka's grandfather ad]|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.it/2015/12/07/nonno-natale-casa-surace_n_8738280.html |publisher=''[[Huffington Post]]'' (Italy) |accessdate = December 22, 2015 |date = December 7, 2015 |language=Italian}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{YouTube|id = V6-0kYhqoRoID|title = #heimkommen}} * {{SoundCloud|edeka-404001891/neele-ternes-dad-edeka-weihnachtsclip-heimkommen}}

{{Infobox book | name = J. R. R. Tolkien Encyclopedia: Scholarship and Critical Assessment | title_orig = | translator = | image = J.R.R. Tolkien Encyclopedia.jpg| caption = | author = [[Michael D. C. Drout]], editor | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] | genre = [[Literature]], [[Essay]]s | publisher = [[Routledge]] | release_date = 2006 | english_release_date = | media_type = Hardcover | pages = 720 | isbn = 978-0415969420 | dewey= 828/.91209 22 | congress= PR6039.O32 Z664 2007 | oclc= 71004244 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} The '''''J. R. R. Tolkien Encyclopedia''''', subtitled ''Scholarship and Critical Assessment'', edited by [[Michael D. C. Drout]], was published by [[Routledge]] in 2006 ({{ISBN|978-0415969420}}). A team of 127 [[Tolkien studies|Tolkien scholars]] on 720 pages covers topics of Tolkien's fiction, his academic works, his intellectual and spiritual influences, and his [[J. R. R. Tolkien|biography]]. Co-editors were [[Douglas A. Anderson]] and [[Verlyn Flieger]] (both Drout's co-editors also of ''[[Tolkien Studies]]''), Marjorie Burns and [[Tom Shippey]].
==See also== *''[[The Lord of the Rings: A Reader's Companion]]'' *''[[The J. R. R. Tolkien Companion and Guide]]''
==References== {{reflist}} *Kelley M. Wickham-Crowley, ''[[Tolkien Studies]]'' 4 (2007) 266-278 [http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/tolkien_studies/v004/4.1wickham-crowley.html ''J.R R. Tolkien Encyclopedia'': Scholarship and Critical Assessment (review)]
==External links== *[http://wormtalk.blogspot.com/2006/11/j.html Drout on the editing process] *[http://users.bestweb.net/~jfgm/EncyclopediaDiary/EncyclopediaReviews.htm A collection of reviews of the ''Encyclopedia'']

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} {{No footnotes|date=April 2009}} }}
'''Jim Graczyk''' (born 1969) is an [[United States|American]] researcher and author on the subject of [[ghosts]]. He is the research assistant for the Ghost Research Society. He is an American non-fiction writer of a series of books in the ''Haunted Field Guide'' series. He is a member of the Society of Midland Authors.
In addition to writing books in the ''Haunted Field Guide'' series, Graczyk has written numerous articles for ''Ghost of the Prairie Magazine'', ''Ghost Trackers Newsletter'' and GhostResearch.org's publication ''The Journal''. He has also appeared in a number of television shows and documentaries about [[ghosts]], including ''Real Ghosthunters'' on the [[Discovery Channel]], ''Basic Ghost Hunting'' by Video Hammer Productions, ''Chicago Ghosts'' by Blue Ghost Productions Incorporated and ''Cringe'' by the IClips Network.
==Bibliography== * ''Field Guide To Chicago Hauntings'' ({{ISBN|0-9766072-2-0}}) * ''Field Guide To Illinois Hauntings'' ({{ISBN|1-892523-26-4}}) * ''Field Guide To The Land Of Lincoln'' ({{ISBN|0-9766072-4-7}}) * ''Field Guide To Mysterious Waters'' ({{ISBN|0-9766072-6-3}}) * ''Field Guide To America's Most Haunted'' ({{ISBN|978-0-9797115-0-3}}) * ''Chicago Hauntings For Teens'' ({{ISBN|978-0-9797115-2-7}})
==External links== * [http://www.ghostguides.com/ Ghost Guides (official site)] * [http://www.ghostresearch.org/ Ghost Research Society] * [http://www.prairieghosts.com/whitechapel.html Whitechapel Press] * [http://www.midlandauthors.com/ Society of Midland Authors]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = John Joseph Albright | image = John J. Albright Portrait.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1848|01|18}} | birth_place = [[Buchanan, Virginia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1931|08|20|1848|01|18}} | death_place = [[Buffalo, New York]] | resting_place = [[Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo|Forest Lawn Cemetery]] | spouse = {{marriage|Harriet Langdon
|1872|1895|reason=her death}}
{{marriage|Susan Fuller
|1897|1931|reason=his death}} | parents = Joseph J. Albright
Elizabeth S. Albright | children = 8, including [[Fuller Albright|Fuller]] | education = [[Williston Northampton School|Williston Academy]] | alma mater = [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] | known_for = [[Albright-Knox Art Gallery]], [[Ontario Power Company]], [[Buffalo Bolt Company]], [[Lackawanna Steel Company]] }} '''John Joseph Albright''' (1 January 1848 [[Buchanan, Virginia]] – 20 August 1931 [[Buffalo, New York]]) was a businessman, philanthropist, and one of Buffalo's leading socialites at the turn of the 20th century. ==Early life== Albright was born on January 18, 1848, in [[Buchanan, Virginia]], to Joseph Jacob Albright and Elizabeth S. Albright, both from Pennsylvania. The family was descended from Andrew Albright, a gunsmith who supplied arms to the troops of the [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], who had come to America in 1750.{{cite book|last1=McCash|first1=June Hall|title=The Jekyll Island Cottage Colony|date=1998|publisher=University of Georgia Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GumIp_e6jWQC&pg=PA189}} Albright's father, Joseph, was an iron manufacturer and eventually, President of the [[First National Bank (Philadelphia)|First National Bank]], coal agent for [[Delaware and Hudson Railway|Delaware and Hudson Canal Company]], and the [[Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad]]. His family lived in [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]] when he was a child and he attended public schools in Scranton, then [[Williston Northampton School|Williston Academy]] in [[Massachusetts]], ultimately graduating from [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] in [[Troy, New York]] with a degree in [[Mining Engineering]] in 1868.{{cite book|last1=Taylor|first1=Betsy|title=The Ivy Grows Again: A History of the Albright Estate from 1890 to the Present|date=1998|publisher=Nardin Academy}} ==Career== [[File:Albright & Company.jpg|thumb|left|Albright & Company Ad from 1890.]] Following his graduation from [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]], Albright returned to Scranton. At that time, coal was in high demand in the [[Western United States]], and Albright got involved in its sale. By 1871, Albright was working out of [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]] selling coal wholesale, along with his business partner, [[Andrew Langdon]] (1835-1919). Their firm was called Langdon, Albright and Company. By 1873, Albright had married Langdon's sister, Harriet, and they all moved to [[Washington, D.C.]], where Albright and Langdon started to work for the [[Reading Anthracite Company|Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company]]. While in Washington, Albright started an [[asphalt]] business with his brother-in-law, [[Amzi L. Barber]] (who had married his wife's sister, Julia Louise Langdon).{{cite book|last1=Lamb|first1=Daniel Smith|title=A Historical, Biographical and Statistical Souvenir|date=1900|publisher=Howard University. Medical Dept.|location=Beresford|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M_gaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA86|accessdate=20 September 2015}} Together Barber and Albright participated in the paving of [[Washington, DC|Washington]], [[Scranton]], and [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]]. While Albright turned to other ventures, Barber continued with the [[asphalt]] business and secured a 42-year [[monopoly]] concession from the [[British Government]] for the [[Pitch Lake]] in [[Trinidad]], the largest natural deposit of asphalt in the world. Barber used the asphalt from [[Trinidad]] for paving city streets and by 1900, Barber had laid over 12 million square yards of [[Trinidad]] [[asphalt]] pavement in 70 American cities at a cost of $35 million.{{cite book|last1=Lamb|first1=Daniel Smith|title=A Historical, Biographical and Statistical Souvenir|date=1900|publisher=Howard University Medical Department|location=Beresford|pages=86|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M_gaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA86|accessdate=17 September 2015}} In 1883, the [[Reading Company|Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company]] tightened its shipping routes and started shipping [[coal]] directly by rail through [[Buffalo, New York]] to ship their coal to the west. Albright moved his family to [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] to oversee the operations. While there, he entered into partnership with [[Thomas Guilford Smith]], another [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute|RPI]] graduate and Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company executive.{{cite book|title=A History of the City of Buffalo: Its Men and Institutions : Biographical Sketches of Leading Citizens|date=1908|publisher=Buffalo Evening News|location=Buffalo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S09KAAAAYAAJ&vq=Moses%2520Taylor%2520marine%2520bank&dq=Moses+Taylor+marine+bank&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} Their firm, Albright & Smith, handled all of Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company's coal sales in [[Canada]] and [[Western New York]], as well as all the Railroad's coal going westward from Buffalo. Albright devised a plan to fill up the empty trains with grain on the haul back to the East. Purportedly, within a year, he had earned $100,000 ({{Inflation|US|100000|1869|r=-3|fmt=eq}}).{{cite web|title=SLC to Joseph J. Albright, 17 July 1874|url=http://www.marktwainproject.org/xtf/view?docId=letters/UCCL01112.xml;style=letter;brand=mtp|website=marktwainproject.org|publisher=The Regents of the University of California|accessdate=20 September 2015}} By 1888, Albright had done so well that he decided to retire and took his family on a 14-month tour of Europe and Egypt when he was only 40 years old. Albright, however, tired of retirement and started working again upon his return. By 1889, Albright's business partner, [[Thomas Guildford Smith|Smith]] had become a sales agent for [[Thomas M. Carnegie|Carnegie, Phipps & Company Limited]] which later merged with The [[Carnegie Steel Company]], of which Smith was its Buffalo representative. ===Ontario Power Company=== In 1890 the US [[Niagara Falls Hydraulic Power and Manufacturing Company]] and its subsidiary Cataract Company formed the International Niagara Commission composed of experts, to analyze proposals to harness [[Niagara Falls]] on the US/Canada border to generate power. They settled electricity ([[alternating current]]) as being the preferred transmission method and, after going through many proposals, in 1893 they awarded the generating contract to [[Westinghouse Electric (1886)|Westinghouse Electric]] with further transmission lines and transformer contracts awarded to [[General Electric]].Robert L. Bradley, Jr., ''Edison to Enron: Energy Markets and Political Strategies'', John Wiley & Sons - 2011, page 40Quentin R. Skrabec, ''The 100 Most Significant Events in American Business: An Encyclopedia'', ABC-CLIO - 2012, page 113 Work began in 1893 and in November 1896, power generated from Niagara Falls at the [[Adams Power Plant Transformer House|Edward Dean Adams Power Plant]] was being sent to [[Buffalo, New York]] as well as the plants of the [[Pittsburgh Reduction Company]] which needed large quantities of cheap electricity for [[smelting]] aluminum.Mark Essig, Edison and the Electric Chair: A Story of Light and Death, Bloomsbury Publishing USA - 2009, page 274 [[File:Boats along the Niagara River, Buffalo, New York, ca. 1905.jpg|thumb|left|Boats along the Niagara River, Buffalo, New York, ca. 1905]] A similar set of events were happening on the Canadian side of the falls. In June 1887, recognizing an opportunity, the [[Ontario Hydro|Ontario Power Company]] of Niagara Falls was incorporated in Canada "to supply manufacturers, corporations, and persons with water, hydraulic, electric or other power." While its operations were in [[Queen Victoria Park]] in [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]], its executive office was in Buffalo with the following officers: Albright, president; [[Francis Vinton Greene|Francis V. Greene]], vice-president; and Robert C. Board, [[Corporate Secretary|secretary]] and treasurer. In 1903, the Company obtained an agreement with the Commissioners of the [[Queen Victoria Park|Queen Victoria Niagara Falls Park]] that allowed the company to develop at least 180,000 [[horsepower]] of [[electricity]]. The company built its [[hydroelectric]] [[generating plant]], which opened in 1905, at the base of the [[Horseshoe Falls]] just above river level. The plant had 15 generators which produced 203,000 horsepower of [[electric power]].{{cite web|title=The Ontario Power Company|url=http://www.niagarafallsinfo.com/history-item.php?entry_id=1441¤t_category_id=248|website=niagarafallsinfo.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}} In 1904, Albright hired Buffalo [[architect]] [[Edward Brodhead Green|E. B. Green]] to design the ''Ontario Power Company'' buildings, Murray Street at Buchanan Avenue, including the Entrance Pavilion, Spillway Building, Office & Transformer Station, Gate House, Screen House, and ‘’Ontario Power Company Generating Station" at river level. The [[hydroelectric]] [[generating plant]] worked by allowing water to enter the generating station from an [[inlet]] located one mile upstream of [[Niagara Falls]], near [[Dufferin Islands]], and was then brought to the plant through buried conduit pipes and steel [[penstock]]s tunneled through the rock.{{cite web|title=Ontario Power Company|url=http://www.niagarafrontier.com/power.html#Ontpower|website=niagarafrontier.com|publisher=Niagara Falls (Ontario) Public Library|accessdate=20 September 2015}} The conduits, two steel and one wooden (bound with iron hoops and encased in cement), ran underground 6,180 feet (1,884 meters) to the top of the generating station. There, each conduit connected with six [[penstock]]s, six feet in diameter. At the point where the conduits and the penstocks join, there was a section which turned upwards into a [[spillway]], called a [[surge tank]]. The [[surge tank]]s served to reduce fluctuations in heat and pressure during both the increase and decrease of loads. The open spillways sent any excess water to the [[Niagara River]] if the load suddenly reduced, which prevented any unwanted rise in pressure. From the distributing station, the [[transmission line]]s carried power at 60,000 [[volt]]s each with a capacity of 40,000 [[kilowatt]]s, running over a right of way that was 300 feet wide and 32,000 feet long. This ran north to an area down the [[Niagara River]] known as [[Devil's Hole State Park|Devil's Hole]], where they then crossed the [[Niagara River]] into [[New York State]] across a 1,300 feet long span. In addition to the high tension [[Electric power distribution|feeders]], there were approximately 30 miles of lines serving [[Canada|Canadian]] customers at generator voltage. The power that was transmitted to [[New York State]] was then sold in bulk to [[The Niagara Lockport and Ontario Power Company|Niagara Lockport and Ontario Power Company]], a New York company, which was then distributed to individual customers. The largest individual consumers of power from these lines included several entities with direct ties to Albright: The [[Lackawanna Steel Company]], [[Empire State Railway]], [[New York Central Railroad]], the [[Shenandoah Steel Wire Company]], the [[Syracuse Consolidated Street Railway|Syracuse Rapid Transit Railway Company]], the [[Lockport Gas and Electric Light Company]], the [[Auburn Light Heat and Power Company]], the [[Erie Railroad|Erie Railroad Company]], and the [[Genesee County Electric Light Power and Gas Company]]. The plant continued to operate until 1999 when the [[Ontario Power Generation]] (formerly [[Ontario Hydro]]) decommissioned the Ontario Power Company Generating Station from service in order to accommodate the construction of [[Niagara Fallsview Casino Resort]], built on the former transformer building location. As of 2015, the 1905 remaining Generating Station is owned by the [[Niagara Parks Commission]], and sits abandoned. ===Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company=== In 1905, a syndicate headed by Albright and [[Henry Herman Westinghouse]] (brother of [[George Westinghouse]]) acquired control [[Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company]] from [[Washington Savings Bank (New York)|Joseph G. Robin]] and his associates. The purchasing syndicate included: Albright, Westinghouse, [[New York Central]], [[William Henry Vanderbilt|Vanderbilt interests]], and Horace E. Andrews, of [[Cleveland]] (president of the [[New York State Railways]], the [[New York State Railways|Mohawk Valley Company]], the Rochester Railway & Light Company, director of the [[Russell, Ontario|New York Central Railway]], the [[Michigan Central Railway]], [[Ontario West Shore Railway|West Shore Railway]], [[New York State Railways|Schenectady Railway Company]], Havana Railway, [[Toronto and Scarboro' Electric Railway, Light and Power Company|Light & Power Company]]), among others. [[File:Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power.gif|thumb|right|Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company Common Stock]] The acquired Company’s officers were: [[Francis Vinton Greene|Francis V. Greene]], president (also vice president of Ontario Power Company); F. B. H. Paine, vice president and chief engineer (formerly export manager of the [[Westinghouse Electric Company|Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company]]); Robert C. Board, [[Corporate Secretary|secretary]] (also [[Corporate Secretary|secretary]] and [[treasurer]] of Ontario Power Company); and Clifford Hubbell, [[treasurer]]. Westinghouse replaced [[Cassius Milton Wicker]] as a director of the Company and the offices of the company moved to the [[Fidelity Trust Building]] in Buffalo. [[Stephen Merrell Clement|Stephen M. Clement]], (president of [[Marine Midland Bank|Marine Bank]]), succeeded [[Washington Savings Bank (New York)|Joseph G. Robin]] on the board of syndicate managers for the [[underwriting]] of the company's [[Security (finance)|securities]]. By 1908, the company had approximately 400 miles of transmission lines running from [[Devil's Hole State Park|Devil's Hole]] through [[Lockport (city), New York|Lockport]] and [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]] to [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]], a total distance of 167 miles from the distributing station. It had branch lines running to [[West Seneca]], [[Batavia, New York|Batavia]], [[Caledonia, New York|Caledonia]], [[Avon, New York|Avon]], [[Auburn, New York|Auburn]], and [[Baldwinsville]] near [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]]. The right of way for the lines was owned by the company and was 300 ft. in width from the [[Niagara River]] to Lockport, 200 ft. from Lockport to Rochester, and 75 ft. the remainder of the way to [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]]. The company also leased a right of way on the [[West Shore Railroad]] from near [[Akron, New York|Akron]] to [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]]. In January 1918, Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company acquired the Salmon River Power Company, which operated their own [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric power plant]] in [[Salmon River (New York)]] on the shore of [[Lake Ontario]].{{cite book|title=Legislative Document, Volume 9 NYS Legislature|date=1919|publisher=New York State Legislature|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LvRBAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA37|accessdate=20 September 2015}} Later in 1943, the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company reorganized as the Niagara Hudson Company, Inc., and became a subsidiary of Niagara Hudson Power Corporation{{cite news|title=Niagara Hudson Power Corporation|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/56338855/|accessdate=20 September 2015|publisher=Dunkirk Evening Observer|date=June 28, 1943}} which was a conglomerate of 59 separate power companies in [[Western New York]] formed in 1929{{cite web|title=History of Niagara Mohawk Corporation|url=http://www.lipsitzponterio.com/JobSites/City/Buffalo/NiagaraMohawk/HistoryandInformation/HistoryofNiagaraMohawk|website=lipsitzponterio.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and in 1932, was the "nation's largest electric utility company".{{cite web|title=The Niagara Hudson Building, Onondaga County, NY|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/feature/weekly_features/10_06_25_Niagara_Hudson_Building.htm|website=nps.gov|accessdate=20 September 2015}} In 1950, Niagara Hudson Power Corporation reorganized as the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation{{cite web|title=Buffalo Power Use|url=http://www.mikalac.com/tech/pow/niagara6.html|website=mikalac.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}} and in January 2002, Niagara Mohawk was acquired by, and became a subsidiary of, [[National Grid plc]].{{cite web|title=Niagara Mohawk Holdings Inc. History|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/niagara-mohawk-holdings-inc-history/|website=fundinguniverse.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}} ===Lackawanna Steel Company=== {{main|Lackawanna Steel Company}} [[File:Blowing Engines Lackawanna Steel 1907.png|thumb|left|Lackawanna Steel in 1907]] In 1889, [[Lackawanna Steel Company|Lackawanna Iron and Steel Company]], at the time the largest steel company in the world, decided to move its facilities out of [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]]. Lackawanna was looking to move away from [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]] because of increases in union labor cost and lack of railroad access to the company's newly emerging markets in the West. They were drawn to [[Western New York]] by the area's easy access to the [[Great Lakes]] and the numerous rail lines in the area.{{cite news|title=A History of the City of Buffalo|url=http://buffaloah.com/h/lacksteel/index.html|publisher=The Buffalo Evening News|date=1908}} Lackawanna Company executives reached out to Buffalo attorney [[John G. Milburn]], who brought in Albright. Albright had been discussing organizing a steel plant in Buffalo with William A. Rogers (vice-president of [[Rogers, Brown & Company]], the largest [[pig iron]] dealer in the [[United States]]), he asked that Rogers be brought into negotiations as well as [[Brig. Gen.]] [[Edmund B. Hayes]] (a [[civil engineer]] and businessman with the [[Union Bridge Company]]). To avoid [[speculation]], the company employed Albright to purchase land on its behalf. In March 1899, the Company’s executives met with Albright, [[John G. Milburn|Milburn]], and Rogers (Hayes was in [[Jekyll Island]] at the time, but returned April 1) in Buffalo and explored several sites, ultimately choosing the undeveloped shoreline on [[Lake Erie]] in what was then the western part of the Town of [[West Seneca, New York|West Seneca]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Albright began purchasing land on April 1, 1899, and by the end of the month had obtained nearly all the required property for a price of $1,095,430.98 ({{Inflation|US|1095431|1899|r=-3|fmt=eq}}). Albright was often accompanied on his purchasing visits by [[John G. Milburn|Milburn]], the president of the [[Pan-American Exposition]], and at the time, many property owners assumed the land purchases were for the [[Pan-American Exposition|Exposition]] which helped them obtain the land at a more reasonable price.{{cite web|last1=LaChiusa|first1=Chuck|title=Steel Plant a Certainty|url=http://buffaloah.com/h/alb/steel.html|website=buffaloah.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}} In 1900, construction on the massive steel mill started and in 1902, the company, of which Albright was then a principal shareholder, was reorganized as the Lackawanna Steel Company. The company moved their headquarters to the site and the plant began operation in 1903, By 1909, the residents of the area voted to split off from [[West Seneca, New York|West Seneca]] and formed the present day city of [[Lackawanna, New York]], named after the Company. The [[Lackawanna Steel Company]] received its power from Albright’s Niagara Lockport and Ontario Power Company and he served as a director of the Lackawanna Steel Company,{{cite news|title= J.J. Albright Dead; Power Developer|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1931/08/21/102256651.pdf|work=The New York Times|date=August 21, 1931}} which remained independent until 1922, when it was acquired by [[Bethlehem Steel]]. ===Depew Improvement Company=== [[File:Plan for the Depew Improvement Company, Depew, NY.jpg|thumb|right|Olmsted Plan for the Depew Improvement Company, Depew, NY]]In 1892, [[New York Central Railroad]] chose the [[Depew, New York]] area (which straddles the towns of [[Lancaster (town), New York|Lancaster]] and [[Cheektowaga (town), New York|Cheektowaga]] and lies to the east of [[Buffalo, New York]]) as a permanent location for its shops and auxiliary establishments. At the time, there was only minimal infrastructure in the area.{{cite web|title=Village of Depew History|url=http://www.villageofdepew.org/about/village-history/|website=villageofdepew.com|publisher=Depew Bee|accessdate=20 September 2015}} [[Chauncey Depew]], attorney for [[Cornelius Vanderbilt]]’s railroad interests and President of New York Central Railroad, formed the Depew Investment Company and purchased 1,000 acres of land north and south of the tracks for their enterprise. The original shareholders included Albright, George Urban, [[Wilson S. Bissell]] and Charles Gould. The officers of the Company were Albright as president and [[James A. Roberts]] as [[Corporate Secretary|secretary]].{{cite book|title=The Olmsted Firm in Buffalo: The Next Generation Arleyn Levee|date=1992|publisher=The Burchfield Art Center|location=Buffalo, NY|url=http://buffaloah.com/h/olm/levee/source/8.html}} The area was eventually called "Depew" in honor of [[Chauncey Depew]]. Albright worked closely with [[Frederick Law Olmsted]] to structure the nucleus of the town. In 1896, the Depew Improvement Company built a brick building at the corner of Transit and Ellicott (now Walden) for a bank, community center and village hall. The Company donated land for the German Lutheran Church, St. Peter and St.Paul, St. James, the Northside Fire House, Depew Village Park, and a [[YMCA]]. The company built streets, houses and the sewer system. ===Buffalo Bolt Company=== In 1897, Albright and [[Edmund B. Hayes]] bought [[Buffalo Bolt Company]], which [[George C. Bell]] had founded in 1859. Buffalo Bolt produced [[nut (hardware)|nuts]] and [[screw|bolts]] that were used by manufacturers in the production of automobiles, ships, trains, household appliances, and hundreds of other products.{{cite news|last1=Neal|first1=Donna Zellner|title=On Buffalo Bolt Co. and Oliver Street|url=http://www.niagara-gazette.com/opinion/guest-view-on-buffalo-bolt-co-and-oliver-street/article_c1de7c48-d25e-54e6-a7b4-e1a8b0afdb72.html|work=Niagara Gazette|date=March 16, 2015}} Under Albright, production increased many times over. In 1869, Buffalo Bolt produced 14,000 nuts and bolts per day, and by 1911, the Company was producing 1,250,000 per day. By 1920, Buffalo Bolt was producing 600,000,000 pieces of bolts, nuts, and screws as well as 5,000 varieties of finished products and 50,000 tons of steel rolled.{{cite web|title=A Graphic Story of the Buffalo Bolt Plant Gallery|url=http://www.nthistorymuseum.org/Collections/boltgal-1.html|website=nthistorymuseum.org|publisher=North Tonawanda History Museum|accessdate=20 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925091104/http://www.nthistorymuseum.org/Collections/boltgal-1.html#|archive-date=2015-09-25|dead-url=yes|df=}} In 1921, the company's main factory was located at 101 East Avenue in [[North Tonawanda, New York]], the general offices were in Buffalo, and the western offices were at 934 [[Monadnock Building]] in [[Chicago, IL]] and 1107 Chemical Building in [[St Louis, Mo]].{{cite book|last1=Larned|first1=Josephus Nelson|title=A History of Buffalo: Delineating the Evolution of the City|date=1921|publisher=Frank P. Bennett & Company|edition=Vol. 32 Iss. 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PyQhAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA2414}} The officers were: Albright, president; [[R. K. Albright]] (Albright's son) and Ralph Plumb, vice presidents; G. A. Mitchell, treasurer; Robert C. Board, secretary. The Board of Directors was composed of: Albright, [[R. K. Albright]], [[Edmund B. Hayes]], Ralph Plumb, G. A. Mitchell, W. P. Cooke, and [[Anson Conger Goodyear]] (son of [[Charles W. Goodyear]]). The need for workers was so great that company paid the costs associated with [[Immigration to the United States|passage to America]] to bring [[Poles|Polish]] and [[Slovaks|Slovakian]] immigrants to the United States to work in their plant in North Tonawanda. The company built a [[company store]] and assisted employees with obtaining housing, with many employees settling in the Oliver Street area of North Tonawanda. ''The Buffalo Bolt Company'', which employed up to 1,500 people at its peak, closed at the end of June 1959. ===Locomobile=== {{main|Locomobile Company of America}} [[File:1903 Poor's Buffalo and Susquehanna Railroad.jpg|thumb|right|Buffalo and Susquehanna Railroad, 1903]] In 1903, Albright’s former brother in law, [[Amzi L. Barber]], was in debt to the extent of $500,000 ({{Inflation|US|500000|1903|r=-3|fmt=eq}}). He had started the [[Locomobile Company of America|Locomobile]] automobile company in 1899 and to keep the company afloat, he surrendered two real estate deals to Albright, who agreed to endorse $300,000 worth of Locomobile [[commercial paper]] and give Barber an annuity of $12,000 ({{Inflation|US|120000|1903|r=-3|fmt=eq}}). He also paid the remaining $100,000 Barber still owed. Unfortunately, the company did not recover financially and was eventually liquidated in 1922, where it was acquired by [[William C. Durant]] of [[Durant Motors]] to compete against [[Rolls Royce Limited|Rolls Royce]] and [[Pierce-Arrow]] (manufactured in Buffalo). ===Buffalo and Susquehanna Iron Company=== {{main|Buffalo and Susquehanna Railroad}} Albright, along with [[Edmund B. Hayes]] and [[Stephen Merrell Clement|Stephen M. Clement]], had invested in [[William A. Rogers]]’ ''Rogers, Brown & Company'' subsidiary, ''The Iroquois Iron Company'', in [[South Chicago, Chicago|South Chicago, Illinois]], which owned a plant containing two [[blast furnace]]s. In 1904, Rogers invited Albright, Hayes and Clement to accompany him on one of his periodic visits, as they had not seen the property before. Purportedly, Frank H. Goodyear, another Buffalo businessman, heard of the trip and offered the use of his private car for the occasion. Rogers accepted and invited Goodyear and his brother [[Charles W. Goodyear]] to join the party. Goodyear was so impressed with the capacity of the plant to produce [[tonnage]] that he wanted one established on the line of the Goodyear brother’s ''[[Buffalo and Susquehanna Railroad]]''. Rogers and the Goodyear Brothers joined forces to create a company and plant in Buffalo that was called the Buffalo and Susquehanna Iron Company, named after the Goodyear brother’s Buffalo and Susquehanna Railroad. Soon after, the ''Buffalo and Susquehanna Railroad'', the ''Buffalo and Susquehanna Iron Company'', the ''[[Pennsylvania Railroad]]'', and the ''[[Lackawanna Steel Company]]'' jointly built a giant ship canal on the border of [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] and [[Lackawanna, New York|Lackawanna]] called the ''Union Ship Canal''. The canal, used by all parties, allowed room for steamships to bring in [[iron ore]] from Michigan and Minnesota to be reduced to [[pig iron]]. The ''Union Ship Canal'''s continued to be used as an industrial waterway until January 1982 with the closure of the [[M. A. Hanna Company|Hanna Blast Furnace]].{{cite web|title=Union Ship Canal (Buffalo, New York)|url=http://wikimapia.org/16740247/Union-Ship-Canal|website=wikimapia.org|publisher=Buffalo Urban Development Corporation|accessdate=20 September 2015}} ==Banking interests== In May 1893, Albright, along with [[George V. Forman]], [[John Satterfield]], and [[Franklin D. Locke]], founded The Fidelity Trust and Guaranty Company of Buffalo, New York.{{cite web|last1=Eck |first1=Susan |title=The Marine: by any other name and address |url=http://wnyheritagepress.org/photos_week_2012/marine_midland/marine_midland_pt1.html |website=wnyheritagepress.org |accessdate=20 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111045022/http://wnyheritagepress.org/photos_week_2012/marine_midland/marine_midland_pt1.html |archivedate=11 November 2013 |df= }} In 1909, [[Edward Brodhead Green|E. B. Green]] was commissioned to build the "[[Fidelity Trust Building]]", today known as "Swan Tower" and owned by [[Ellicott Development Co.]], located at 284 Main Street in Buffalo.[[File:Views of Old-Time Buffalo p32.jpg|thumb|right|"Manufacturer's & Traders National Bank" on the left and "Fidelity Trust Company" on the right, 1916]] In December 1925, the Fidelity Trust Company, with $35 million in assets, merged with [[M&T Bank|Manufacturers and Traders Bank]], founded in 1856, with $64 million in assets, under the new name [[M&T Bank|Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company]]. The $100 million company was headed by Fidelity's President, 36-year-old [[Lewis G. Harriman]]. Harriman and a group of investors including [[A. H. Schoellkopf]], from the founding family of the [[Niagara Falls Hydraulic Power and Manufacturing Company]], and [[James Forrestal]], who would become the first [[United States Secretary of Defense]], owned enough shares to control both Fidelity and [[M&T Bank|M&T]].{{cite web|title=M&T Bank Celebrates 150 Years|url=http://ir.mandtbank.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=208314|website=mandtbank.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}} ===Marine National Bank=== {{main|Marine Midland Bank}} In 1908, separate from his involvement with The Fidelity Trust and Guaranty Company, Albright served as vice president of [[Marine Midland Bank|Marine Bank]]'s [[Board of Directors]], along with [[Stephen M. Clement]] (president), [[Charles W. Goodyear]] (founder of the [[Great Southern Lumber Company]]), [[William H. Gratwick]] (founder of the lumber firm of [[Gratwick, Smith & Fryer Lumber Co]].), [[Edmund B. Hayes]] ([[civil engineer]] and businessman with the [[Union Bridge Company]]), [[William H. Hotchkiss]] (a lawyer with Hotchkiss & Bush and later [[New York State Insurance Department|State Superintendent of Insurance]]), [[Edward H. Hutchinson]] (of Maerz Lithographing Co.), [[Charles H. Keep]] ([[Corporate Secretary|secretary]] of the Lake Carriers' Association and of the Buffalo Merchants' Exchange), [[John H. Lascelles]] (director of the [[Buffalo and Susquehanna Railroad]]), [[George B. Mathews]] (Partner at [[Jacob F. Schoellkopf|Schoellkopf & Mathews]] flour mill), [[Moses Taylor Pyne|Moses Taylor]], and [[Cornelius Vanderbilt III]]. Albright served as President of Marine National Bank of Buffalo and later as director of the Marine Trust Company. ==Philanthropy== ===Albright Memorial Building=== {{main|Albright Memorial Building}} In 1890, Albright hired [[Edward Brodhead Green|E. B. Green]] of [[Edward Brodhead Green|Green & Wicks]] to design the [[Albright Memorial Building]] in [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]], in honor of his parents. The building, also known as "Scranton Public Library," was completed in early 1893 and is a two-story, "L"-shaped, Indiana [[limestone]] and Medina [[sandstone]] building with [[Châteauesque]]-style design elements.{{cite web|last1=LaChiusa|first1=Chuck|title=Albright Memorial Library|url=http://buffaloah.com/a/virtual/us/scran/Alb/ext/index.html|website=buffaloah.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}} The building was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1978.{{cite web| url = https://www.dot7.state.pa.us/ce/SelectWelcome.asp| title = National Historic Landmarks & National Register of Historic Places in Pennsylvania| publisher = CRGIS: Cultural Resources Geographic Information System| format = Searchable database}} ''Note:'' This includes {{cite web| url = {{NRHP-PA|H000638_01H.pdf}}| title = National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Albright Memorial Building| accessdate = 2012-01-02| author = Dorothy Reddington| format = PDF| date= September 1977}} ===Schools and churches=== In 1892, Albright helped found the [[Nichols School]] by bringing William Nichols to Buffalo to set up the school, and supported the ''Elmwood School'' (which merged with the Franklin School in 1941 to form the Elmwood Franklin School), the oldest independent school in [[Western New York]], founded in 1889. In 1904, he donated the land for the [[Unitarian Universalist Church of Buffalo]] and gave significant donations to the [[Buffalo and Erie County Botanical Gardens|South Park Botanical Gardens]].{{cite web|title=The John J. Albright Society|url=http://www.albrightknox.org/join-support/planned-giving/the-john-j-albright-society/|website=albrightknox.org|accessdate=20 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923164033/http://www.albrightknox.org/join-support/planned-giving/the-john-j-albright-society/#|archive-date=2015-09-23|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===Albright Art Gallery=== His largest gift was in 1900 when he made a donation of $350,000 ({{Inflation|US|350000|1900|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) so that the then ‘’Fine Arts Academy", founded in 1862, could have a permanent home. The building was designed by prominent architect [[Edward Brodhead Green|Green]] and was originally intended to be used as the Fine Arts Pavilion for the [[Pan-American Exposition]] in 1901, but delays in its construction and increased costs (the total cost was purported to be closer to $1,000,000 ({{Inflation|US|1000000|1905|r=-3|fmt=eq}})) caused it to remain uncompleted until 1905, when it opened as the [[Albright–Knox Art Gallery|Albright Art Gallery]]. The [[Pan-American Exposition]] was held in Buffalo from May 1, 1901 through November 2, 1901.{{cite web|title=History of the 1905 Albright Art Gallery|url=http://buffaloah.com/a/elmwd/1285/albhist.html|website=buffaloah.com|accessdate=20 September 2015}} [[Edward Brodhead Green|Green]] designed the gallery along the lines of a Greek temple and included 102 columns, more than any other American structure except the [[United States Capitol|Capitol Building]] in Washington. The building was constructed using 5,000 tons of white marble from a [[Maryland]] quarry, the same marble used in the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in [[New York City]] and the [[Washington Monument]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web|title=The Gift of the Albright Art Gallery 1900 - 1905|url=http://wnyheritagepress.org/photos_week_2015/albright_knox/construction/construction.html|website=wnyheritagepress.org|accessdate=20 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150927092814/http://wnyheritagepress.org/photos_week_2015/albright_knox/construction/construction.html|archivedate=27 September 2015|df=}} When the Gallery opened on May 31, 1905, [[Harvard University]] President, [[Charles William Eliot]], gave the [[keynote]] address and four city [[choral]] organizations performed together. [[Richard Watson Gilder]] read a poem he had written celebrating the gallery's opening. Albright, however, did not give a speech or appear in any photographs from the ceremony as he had always been inclined to avoid the spotlight. Birge Albright, his grandson, said that Albright took friends to the gallery on Sundays when there were few others around. File:Albright Memorial Library 3.jpg|[[Albright Memorial Building]] File:Albright Memorial Library 2.jpg|[[Albright Memorial Building]] - Detail File:Nichols School Albright Hall Buffalo, N.Y..jpg|[[Nichols School]] Albright Hall File:Unitarian Church of Buffalo.jpg|[[Unitarian Universalist Church of Buffalo]] File:Albright Art Gallery 1913.jpg|[[Albright–Knox Art Gallery|Albright Art Gallery]] in 1913 File:Albright Art Gallery Statues.jpg|[[Augustus St. Gaudens]] "porch of the maidens" on the [[Albright–Knox Art Gallery|Albright Art Gallery]] ==Personal life== In 1872, Albright married Harriet Langdon (1847–1895), the sister of his business partner, [[Andrew Langdon]]. Harriet and Andrew were first cousins with [[Olivia Langdon Clemens]] (1845–1904), the wife of [[Samuel Langhorne Clemens]] (1835–1910), also known as [[Mark Twain]]. Olivia, who was originally from a wealthy family in [[Elmira, New York]], and Twain lived in Buffalo from 1869 to 1871 where Twain owned a stake in the ''[[Buffalo Courier-Express|Buffalo Express]]'' newspaper and worked as an editor and writer. Together, John and Harriet had three children together, all born in [[Washington D.C.]]: Raymond King Albright, Ruth Albright, and Langdon Albright. In 1895, Susan Fuller (1868–1928) was brought to Buffalo to educate the three Albright children. In March 1897, within two years of her arrival in Buffalo, 28-year-old Susan (daughter of Eben and Nancy Fuller) married 49-year-old Albright. Fuller was a recent [[Smith College]] graduate from [[Lancaster, Massachusetts]]. The couple honeymooned at the [[Jekyl Island Club]]. Together, John and Susan had five children: John "Jack" Joseph Albright Jr., Elizabeth "Betty" Albright, [[Fuller Albright]], Nancy Albright, and Susan "Susy" Albright.{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=SUSAN ALBRIGHT REED, GALLERY FOUNDER'S KIN|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-22764049.html|accessdate=3 April 2016|work=[[The Buffalo News]] |date=November 5, 1995}} In 1915, Albright and two of his daughters, were painted by [[Edmund Charles Tarbell]]. The oil painting, entitled ''John J. Albright and His Daughters'', is owned by the [[Westmoreland Museum of American Art]] in [[Greensburg, Pennsylvania]]. Tarbell also painted a portrait of Albright that is currently at the Albright-Knox gallery.{{cite web|title=PORTRAIT OF FATHER AND CHILDREN (JOHN J. ALBRIGHT)|url=https://www.1000museums.com/art_works/edmund-charles-tarbell-portrait-of-father-and-children-john-j-albright|website=1000museums.com|publisher=1000 Museums|accessdate=7 March 2016}} John J. Albright died on August 20, 1931, at the age of 83, six weeks after an intestinal operation. He is buried with his family at the [[Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo]]. ===Clubs and memberships=== Albright was elected a director of The [[Buffalo Fine Arts Academy]] in 1887, served as president from 1895 to 1897, and remained on the Board until 1910. He was also a member Jekyll Island Club from 1890 until his death in 1931. He was a member of the [[American Academy in Rome]], the Buffalo Club, the University Club of Buffalo, the [[Country Club of Buffalo]], and [[Delta Phi]]. In April 1926, Albright sold many valuable paintings and works of art, including: a [[Anton Mauve|Mauve]], a [[Charles Jacque|Jacque]], two by [[Narcisse Virgilio Díaz|Diaz]], a [[Emile Claus|Claus]], a [[Constant Troyon|Troyon]], and others by André Crochepierre, Louis Adan, [[Abbott Handerson Thayer|Abbott H. Thayer]] and a [[Thomas Lawrence|Lawrence]] portrait of [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]], at the [[American Art Association|Anderson Galleries]] in [[New York City]] as a gift to Buffalo.{{cite news|title=Paintings Put On Sale|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/04/11/issue.html|work=The New York Times|date=April 11, 1926}} In February 1929, the [[University at Buffalo]] conferred upon Albright the Chancellor’s Medal, its highest honor, recognition of his achievements throughout his life. Albright's second wife, Susan, was a member of the "Board of Women Managers' Entertainment & Ceremony" sub-committee and the ‘’Committee on Fine Arts" for the [[Pan American Exposition]]. Susan died on June 19, 1928. ===Residences=== In 1887, Albright acquired the [[James Wadsworth (mayor)|Wadsworth]]'s House, former [[mayor of Buffalo, New York|mayor of Buffalo]], at 730 [[Upper West Side, Buffalo, New York|West Ferry]] in Buffalo. In 1890 he hired the [[Olmsted Brothers|Olmsted Firm]] to design the grounds. When the house was destroyed by fire in 1901, he hired [[Edward Brodhead Green|Green & Wicks]] to design a new Tudor style home. The [[Olmsted Brothers|Olmsted]]'s work for Albright continued until 1907. [[Edward Brodhead Green|E. B. Green]] designed the new Albright mansion after the [[manor house]] of [[St. Catherine's Court]] in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] [[England]]. A former neighbor of the Albrights recalled, "It was a huge house. It was not unlike the [[Canisius High School|Rand House]] on Delaware". When the property was first built, the streets Tudor Place and St. Catherine's Court did not exist. The property had a red brick wall that surrounded the estate. Local writer Edwine Noye Mitchell wrote that the gray stone house, was surrounded "by terraces where the [[crocus]] and [[scilla]] pushed up between the flagstones in the spring, and the pink magnolia blossoms lay thick over the grass from the sidewalk. The Albrights' property ran from 690 to 770 West Ferry and extended from West Ferry to Cleveland Avenue on at least 12 acres of land. In 1935, the Albright house on West Ferry was demolished and the estate was sold in multiple parcels for homes to be built on. Green salvaged the stone [[balustrade]] from the terrace and had it reinstalled in front of [[University at Buffalo Libraries|Lockwood Library]] at the [[University of Buffalo]]'s Main Street campus soon after. A wrought iron gate, known today as "Queen Anne's Gate" and which still stands [[Border guard|sentinel]] outside of the property.{{cite web|title=John J. Albright Estate, West Ferry Street|url=http://wnyheritagepress.org/photosofweek/albrightestate.htm|website=wnyheritagepress.org|accessdate=20 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926135305/http://wnyheritagepress.org/photosofweek/albrightestate.htm|archivedate=26 September 2015|df=}} In February 1914, Albright and his second wife Susan, purchased the 26 room [[Joseph Pulitzer]] Cottage, in [[Jekyl Island]], in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], fully furnished, after spending many winters on the island with their family. While there, the Albrights struck up a friendship with the poet laureate of England, [[Alfred Noyes]] and his wife, who visited them in Jeykl Island in 1914. Albright introduced Noyes to [[William Rockefeller]] and other Jekyl Islanders who were at the club. The house was sold in 1931 after Albrights death and when the State of Georgia acquired the entire Jekyl Island in 1947, the cottage was still standing. In 1951, a fire damaged the interior and on June 23, 1951, the cottage was demolished as there were no funds were available to repair the damage. File:Albright Estate Entrance.jpg|Albright Estate entrance File:Albright Lawn.jpg|Albright Estate view from the lawn File:Albright Side.jpg|Albright Estate view from the side ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Albright, John J.}} [[Category:1848 births]] [[Category:1931 deaths]] [[Category:American business executives]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Buffalo, New York]] [[Category:Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute alumni]] [[Category:Burials at Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo]] [[Category:Albright–Knox Art Gallery]] [[Category:People from Buchanan, Virginia]]

{| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:0 0.5em 0.5em 1em; font-size:95%;" ! colspan=3 | Karl Jäger Report |- | colspan=3 |[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-B0716-0005-007, Oberstes Gericht, Globke-Prozess, Beweisstück.jpg|200px]] |- style="font-size:90%;" ! MonthGrouped by the ending date of the massacre || Entries || Killed |- style="font-size:90%;" | June || 1 entry || 4,000 |- style="font-size:90%;" | July || 20 entries || 4,400 |- style="font-size:90%;" | August || 33 entries || 47,906 |- style="font-size:90%;" | September || 38 entries || 40,997 |- style="font-size:90%;" | October || 12 entries || 31,829 |- style="font-size:90%;" | November || 10 entries || 8,211 |} The so-called '''Jäger Report''', also Jaeger Report (full title: ''Complete tabulation of executions carried out in the Einsatzkommando 3 zone up to December 1, 1941''){{cite journal |title=The Jaeger Report: A Chronicle of Nazi Mass Murder |work=English translation of the Report along with scanned images of the original |publisher=The Holocaust History Project |url=http://phdn.org/archives/holocaust-history.org/works/jaeger-report/htm/img001.htm.en.html |author=Karl Jäger, Commander of the Security Police and the SD, Einsatzkommando 3 |location=Kauen |date=December 1, 1941 |at=webpages 1–9 with transcriptions of photostat facsimiles}} was written on 1 December 1941 by [[Karl Jäger]], commander of [[Einsatzkommando|''Einsatzkommando'' 3]] (EK 3), a [[death squad|killing unit]] of [[Einsatzgruppen|''Einsatzgruppe'' A]] which was attached to [[Army Group North]] during the [[Operation Barbarossa]]. It is the most detailed and precise surviving chronicle of the activities of one individual ''Einsatzkommando'', and a key record documenting [[the Holocaust in Lithuania]] as well as in [[the Holocaust in Latvia|Latvia]] and [[the Holocaust in Belarus|Belarus]]. ==Description== [[File:Map used to illustrate Stahlecker's report to Heydrich on January 31, 1942.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Map Stahlecker attached to his report to [[Reinhard Heydrich]] using the execution tally from the updated Jäger's report]] The Jäger Report is a tally sheet of actions by ''Einsatzkommando'' 3, including the [[Rollkommando Hamann|''Rollkommando'' Hamann]] killing squad. The report keeps an almost daily running total of the murders of 137,346 people, the vast majority Jews, from 2 July 1941 to 25 November 1941. The report documents date and place of the massacres, number of victims and their breakdown into categories (Jews, communists, criminals, etc.). In total, there were 112 executions in 71 different locations in Lithuania, Latvia, and Belarus. On 17 occasions, daily casualties exceeded 2,000 people. On 9 February 1942, in a handwritten note for [[Franz Walter Stahlecker]], Jäger updated the totals to 138,272 people: 136,421 Jews (46,403 men, 55,556 women and 34,464 children), 1,064 [[communist]]s, 653 mentally disabled, and 134 others. The report concluded that Lithuania was now [[Judenfrei|free of Jews]] except for about 34,500 Jews concentrated in [[Vilna Ghetto|Vilnius]], [[Kovno Ghetto|Kaunas]] and [[Šiauliai Ghetto]]s. However, Jäger Report did not tally all Jewish deaths in Lithuania as it did not include executions by ''Einsatzkommando'' 2 in [[Šiauliai]] area (approx. 46,000 people), in some border areas (for example, in [[Šakiai]] on September 13, [[Kudirkos Naumiestis]] on September 19, [[Kretinga]] in July–August, [[Gargždai]] on June 24, 1941), or even in Vilnius (for example, the report is missing the October 1 ([[Yom Kippur]]) massacre of some 4,000 Jews). The nine-page report was prepared in five copies, but only one survives and is kept by the Special Archive, part of the {{illm|Russian State Military Archive|ru|Российский государственный военный архив}} in [[Moscow]]. The copy was discovered in 1944 when Red Army recaptured Lithuania, but it was not made known to scholars or the judiciary evaluating Nazi war crimes. Only in 1963, during the ''[[in absentia]]'' trial of [[Hans Globke]] in [[East Germany]] and four years after Jäger's suicide, Soviet [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Soviet Union)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] disclosed the document to the German [[Central Office of the State Justice Administrations for the Investigation of National Socialist Crimes]]. The document was first published in a Lithuanian collection of documents ''Masinės žudynės Lietuvoje'' in 1965 and in Western press by {{illm|Adalbert Rückerl|de}} in 1972 as a [[facsimile]]. {{clear}} ==Report tabulation== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%;" ! rowspan=2 | Date{{cite book| title="The Good Old Days": The Holocaust as Seen by Its Perpetrators and Bystanders |first1=Ernst |last1=Klee |first2= Willi |last2=Dressen |first3=Volker |last3=Riess |year=1988 |publisher=The Free Press |isbn=9781568521336 |pages=46–58 |url=http://fcit.usf.edu/holocaust/resource/document/DocJager.htm}} ! rowspan=2 | Location ! colspan=3 | JewsIf breakdown of Jews not specified, men, women and children are included in a single column ! rowspan=2 | OthersIncludes mostly communists and mentally ill ! rowspan=2 | TotalTotal is given per original report. Errors in addition are noted with "(Error in math)". ! rowspan=2 | Notes |- ! Men !! Women !! {{Infobox COA case |Litigants=Kincaid v. Gibson |Court=[[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]] |CourtSeal= |ArgueDate=May 30, |ArgueYear=2000 |DecideDate=January 5, |DecideYear=2001 |FullName=Charles Kincaid, et al v. Betty Gibson, et al |Citations=236 F. 3d 342 (6th Cir. 2001) |Prior=[https://openjurist.org/191/f3d/719 191 F.3d 719] (1999)
Rehearing ''[[en banc]]'' granted, 197 F.3d 828 (1999) |Subsequent= |Holding= |Judges=[[Boyce F. Martin Jr.]], [[Gilbert S. Merritt Jr.]], [[James L. Ryan]], [[Danny Julian Boggs]], [[Alan Eugene Norris]], [[Richard Fred Suhrheinrich]], [[Eugene Edward Siler Jr.]], [[Alice M. Batchelder]], [[Martha Craig Daughtrey]], [[Karen Nelson Moore]], [[R. Guy Cole Jr.]], [[Eric L. Clay]], [[Ronald Lee Gilman]] |Majority=Cole |JoinMajority=Martin, Merritt, Siler, Daughtrey, Moore, Clay, Gilman |Concurrence=Ryan |Concurrence/Dissent=Boggs |Dissent=Norris |JoinDissent=Suhrheinrich, Batchelder |LawsApplied=[[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] }} '''''Kincaid v. Gibson''''', 236 F. 3d 342 (6th Cir. 2001) was a [[United States]] court case before the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]] dealing with [[freedom of expression]]. Charles Kincaid and Carpi Coffer, students at [[Kentucky State University]], filed the suit against Betty Gibson, KSU's Vice President for Student Affairs. The Kentucky State University reviewed the 1992-1994 edition of The Thoroughbred Yearbook and the administration decided that it was not satisfactory and locked it in a closet. In particular the administration did not feel as though the yearbook should have a section with current events and they did not like the fact that the school colors were not on the yearbook. Charles Kincaid and Carpi Coffer filed suit on behalf of the students against the university. Initially the lower courts ruled in favor of the school using the ''[[Hazelwood v. Kuhlmeier]]'' case as an example of how students can be censored by school administrations. Eventually the case made it all the way to the Sixth Court of Appeals. After failing to win a decision the students appealed to have the circuit court rule ''[[en banc]]''. The court heard the case on Jan. 5, 2001 and by a 10-3 decision decided for the students. This is significant because the court made it clear that the ''Hazelwood'' case should not be applied to the college media. In March 2001, the students and KSU settled with money and attorney's fees changing hands to the students. Also the students, seven years later, received their yearbook that they had paid for in 1994. ==External Links== * http://www.thefileroom.org * http://www.belcherfoundation.org/kincaid_v_gibson.htm {{DEFAULTSORT:Kincaid V. Gibson}} [[Category:United States Free Speech Clause case law]] [[Category:United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit cases]] [[Category:2001 in United States case law]] [[Category:Kentucky State University]] [[Category:Yearbooks]] [[Category:Student rights case law in the United States]] {{US-case-law-stub}}

'''Les Arts Décoratifs''' is a private, non-profit [[museum]] of decorative arts located in [[Paris]], [[France]].
==History and Operations== The museum dates to 1882, when collectors with an interest in the applied arts formed the initial organization. For many years it was known as the Union centrale des Arts décoratifs (UCAD), but in December 2004 it was renamed Les Arts Decoratifs. Pamela Golbin is the chief curator of fashion and textiles at Les Arts Décoratifs.<ref name="Dries Van Noten's Divine Inspiration">{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/eye/fashion/dries-van-notens-divine-inspiration-7523340?src=n/newsAlert/20140228-1 | title=Dries Van Noten's Divine Inspiration | publisher=WWD | date=28 February 2014 | accessdate=28 February 2014 | author=Socha, Miles}}</ref>
The museum currently occupies three sites, with the Ateliers du Carrousel (art and craft workshops) active at all three:
* 107 rue de Rivoli, in the [[Louvre]]'s Rohan and Marsan wings — [[Musée des Arts Décoratifs, Paris|Musée des Arts Décoratifs]] * 63 rue de Monceau — the [[Musée Nissim de Camondo]] in the Hôtel Camondo. * 266 boulevard Raspail — École Camondo, school of design and interior architecture.
As of 2006, its collections included approximate 357,100 works as follows:
* Arts Décoratifs — 150,000 works from medieval furniture to contemporary design, including Empire, Art Nouveau and Art Deco styles; large collections of jewelry, toys, wallpaper, gold work, ceramics, glass, drawings and an Islamic and Oriental collection. * Publicité — 100,000 historical and contemporary posters as well as over 20,000 French and foreign advertising films from the 1930s to the present day; radio commercials, promotional objects, packaging, and more from the formerly separate [[Musée de la Publicité]]. * Mode et textile — 86,000 costumes, accessories, and textiles from Copts to the present day; from the formerly separate [[Musée de la mode et du textile]]. * Musée Nissim de Camondo — 1,100 works; one of the finest sets of French furniture and [[objets d'art]] from the second half of the 18th century. * In May 2007, Les Arts Décoratifs exhibited Love & Art Children's Foundation's "L'Enfant et l'Art" collection. This art collection was created by children afflicted with cancer at the Hospital Armand Trousseau in sterilized rooms and by children in remission in Les Ateliers du Carrousel under the guidance of Love & Art's founder, artist Alécia de Menezes Seidler.
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:1949 m. Lietuvos Laisvės Kovos Sąjūdžio Tarybos Deklaracija.jpg|thumb|February 16, 1949 Declaration by Union of Lithuanian Freedom Fighters]] '''Lithuanian Partisans Declaration of February 16, 1949''' ({{lang-lt|Lietuvos laisvės kovos sąjūdžio deklaracija}}) is a document, created by [[Lithuanian partisans]] and signed by [[Union of Lithuanian Freedom Fighters]] (ULFF) on February 16, 1949 in [[Minaičiai]] ([[Radviliškis District Municipality]]). By signing the declaration, the ULFF assumed responsibility to lead the restoration of independent democratic state of [[Lithuania]], where equal rights for all citizens and social care is guaranteed. Document also states that "[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Communist party]], as dictatorial and essentially opposite to the main aim of Lithuanian nation and keystone provision of the Constitution – independence of Lithuania, – is not considered a legal party". The declaration appeals to the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], [[Lithuanian Constitution of 1922]] and addresses whole democratic world asking for help.
Declaration was signed by the chairman of ULFF Council Presidium [[Jonas Žemaitis|Jonas Žemaitis-Vytautas]] and members of the Council: [[Aleksandras Grybinas-Faustas]], [[Vytautas Gužas-Kardas]], [[Juozas Šibaila-Merainis]], [[Bronislovas Liesis-Naktis]], [[Leonardas Grigonis-Užpalis]], [[Adolfas Ramanauskas|Adolfas Ramanauskas-Vanagas]] and [[Petras Bartkus-Žadgaila]].
In 1996, [[Seimas]] recognized the Declaration as an official act of the Republic of Lithuania and Žemaitis as a [[President of Lithuania]].
In 2010, eight partisans, who had signed the Declaration, were awarded with status of signatories. The status (posthumously) was awarded to Bartkus, Grigonis, Grybinas, Gužas, Liesis, Ramanauskas, Šibaila and Žemaitis.
On November 22, 2010, a monument was unveiled in [[Minaičiai]] to honor the Declaration and its signatories (author – sculptor Jonas Jagėla). The barn and the bunker, where the Declaration had been signed, were restored in 2012 to house an exposition "Give the Homeland what you have to" ({{lang-lt|Atiduok Tėvynei, ką privalai}}).
== Literature == * Auksutė Ramanauskaitė-Skokauskienė. Laisvės deklaracija ir jos signatarai – Kaunas: Naujasis lankas, 2009. – 56 p.: iliustr. – {{ISBN|978-9955-03-535-0}} * Lietuvos ypatingasis archyvas, f. K-1, ap. 58, b. 33960/3, t. 10, l. 227 * [http://kauno.diena.lt/dienrastis/lietuva/partizanu-bunkeryje-gimusi-deklaracija-199185 Partizanų bunkeryje gimusi deklaracija // Kauno diena, 2009-02-07]

{{Live 8}} [[File:Philaartmusliv8.jpg|thumb|View of Live 8 crowd along the Benjamin Franklin Parkway]] On 2 July 2005, a [[Live 8]] concert was held in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] in front of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]], with a densely packed audience stretched out for one mile along the [[Benjamin Franklin Parkway]]. The event was organized by the [[ONE Campaign]].
It was one of the first Live 8 concerts announced, as the city had played host to its [[Live Aid]] predecessor in 1985, and, until the inclusion of a concert outside [[Toronto]], was the only city in [[North America]] to represent Live 8. It did, however, remain the only [[United States]] city to participate in the event.
The event is also referred to as '''"Live 8 Philadelphia"''', '''"Live 8 Philly"''', or '''"Live 8 USA"'''.
Unlike other venues, no tickets were issued to control access, and Philadelphia police declined to give a crowd estimate. Presenters stated several times on stage that over one million people were at the concert. Non-organizer estimates ranged from 600,000 to 800,000 and one million to 1.5 million. Some estimates are of the number of people at the concert at any one time, while other estimates are of the total number of people on the Parkway over the course of the nearly 8 hour-long event.
==Lineup==

==Performance notes== [[File:Destiny's Child Live 8.jpg|thumb|Destiny's Child at Live 8]]
Several artists mentioned or dedicated performances to [[Luther Vandross]] who had died the day before.
The show managed to expose fault in the [[SEPTA Regional Rail]] system, which is the commuter rail portion of the city's mass transit system, [[SEPTA]]. Trains to and from the concert were overcrowded and many had to ignore departure times in order to accommodate the unprecedented influx of passengers using the system at one time.
Two days after the concert, [[Elton John]] gave a free concert on the same stage used for Live 8, as part of the city's [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] celebrations.
==Pre-show news and rumours== Live 8 producer/promoter [[Russell Simmons]] was the man responsible for adding more [[African American]] artists to the Live 8 Philadelphia bill, including some [[Def Poetry Jam]] poets.
After noticing the lack of hip-hop artists on the bill, [[Bono]] called Jay-Z and [[Mike Shinoda]] of [[Linkin Park]] personally and asked them to perform in Philadelphia. [[50 Cent]], [[Justin Timberlake]], [[Usher Raymond|Usher]], and [[Sean Combs]] were also originally scheduled to perform but cancelled due to scheduling conflicts.
Despite suspicions that the show's finale would consist of a new rendition of the [[USA for Africa]] hit "[[We Are the World]]", which was performed at the Philadelphia show twenty years ago at [[Live Aid]], it did not.
Also, rumors circulated in the crowd that Bruce Springsteen would close the show.
==Coverage==
In the United States, [[MTV]] and [[VH1]] provided intermittent and incomplete live and taped coverage, frequently breaking away mid-song for commercials or commentary by their veejays. [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] provided a short highlights program that evening.
In the United Kingdom, [[BBC One]] aired highlights after the full coverage of the [[Live 8 concert, London|London show]]. Furthermore, [[BBC Three]] aired further highlights the following evening. [[Clair Companies|Clair Brothers Audio Systems]] and [[Franklin Simon Productions]] were responsible for providing the live sound reinforcement for Live 8 Philadelphia. [[Electric Factory Concerts]] was also involved in the production. Clair Brothers also provided the live sound reinforcment for Live 8 London. The remaining venues were handled by local sound reinforcement companies.
[[AOL]] also provided a [[webcast]] of the entire show as it happened and carried webcasts of almost all of the Live 8 shows.
==References== *[http://WWW.LIVE8.US/ Live 8 Philadelphia exclusive website]. *[http://dragonballyee.com/live8 Live 8 photo gallery].

[[File:Milo C. Beach.jpg|thumb|right|Milo C. Beach in 1986]] '''Milo Cleveland Beach''' is an [[art historian]] and the former director of the [[Arthur M. Sackler Gallery]] and the [[Freer Gallery of Art]].
Beach is a historian of [[Indian art]], specifically Indian painting.<ref name=SIA1/><ref name=NYTA>{{cite news|title=Director at Sackler and Freer Named|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/24/arts/director-at-sackler-and-freer-named.html|accessdate=11 May 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=24 October 1988}}</ref> He graduated from [[Harvard College]] and credits the music of [[Ravi Shankar]] for garnering his interest in Indian culture. Before earning his Ph.D. at Harvard, he was already a curator at the [[Fogg Art Museum]] and [[Boston Museum of Fine Arts]].<ref name=Richard/> He is a world-renowned expert on Mughal painting of the Akbar to Shah Jahan periods and has published important catalogues on the subject including ''The Grand Mogul: Imperial Painting in India 1600-1660'' (Williamstown, 1978), now a classic in its field.[https://books.google.ca/books/about/The_grand_Mogul.html?id=cw7rAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y]
He served as the chair of the art department at [[Williams College]].<ref name=SIA2 /> He became director of the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[Arthur M. Sackler Gallery]] in 1984.<ref name=SIA1>{{cite web|title=Milo C. Beach|url=http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_sic_9909|publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution Archives]]|accessdate=10 May 2012}}</ref><ref name=SIA2>{{cite web|title=Beach to Head Sackler Gallery|url=http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_sic_2183|work=Record Unit 371, Box 4, "The Torch," April 1984, p. 1|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Archives|accessdate=11 May 2012}}</ref> He supervised the opening of the Sackler Gallery and acquired loans for the opening exhibitions from the government of [[China]], the Queen of England, [[Elizabeth II]], [[Emperor Shōwa]], the [[Topkapi Museum]], and the [[Hermitage Museum]]. A $26 million renovation of the Freer also took place during his tenure.<ref name=Richard>{{cite news|last=Richard|first=Paul|title=Sackler, Freer Director To Retire; Milo Beach to Return To Art Scholarship|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-413973.html|accessdate=11 May 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=20 March 2011}}</ref> Beach curated numerous exhibitions, including the collection of painter [[Howard Hodgkin]], Japanese [[pop art]], the art of [[Hiroshima Kazuo]], and contemporary pottery.<ref name=Richard/>
In 1993, Beach published his research on the British [[Royal Collection]]'s 17th-century manuscript of the ''[[Padshahnama]]''. The [[Royal Librarian (United Kingdom)|Royal Librarian]] described the publication as the "best catalogue ever produced for an exhibition from [[Windsor Castle]]."<ref name=Richard/> In October, 2001, Beach retired as the director of both the Sackler and the [[Freer Gallery of Art]]. Beach returned to research, specifically focusing on the work of the [[Mughal Empire]].<ref name=Richard/>

[[San Nicolaas]], [[Aruba]] | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | director = J. de Vries | president = | chairperson = | curator = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = | embedded = }} The '''Model Trains Museum''' is a [[private museum]] in the town of [[San Nicolaas]] in [[Aruba]]. It covers the history of train traffic from 1875 to the present.{{cite book |last=Alofs |first=L. |title=The Aruba Heritage Report |publisher=Aruba National Commission for Unesco |date=2003 |url=http://awad.kitlv.nl/pdf//UNESCO%20report%20Luc%20Alofs%20okt08.pdf |format=pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426071225/http://awad.kitlv.nl/pdf//UNESCO%20report%20Luc%20Alofs%20okt08.pdf |archivedate=26 April 2012}} ({{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/64ActJXAA?url=http://awad.kitlv.nl/pdf//UNESCO%20report%20Luc%20Alofs%20okt08.pdf |date=December 24, 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2017}}) The museum is on the ground floor of a private residence, and includes model trains from England, Germany, the U.S., and Canada, and a number of model planes and automobiles as well. == See also == * [[List of museums in Aruba]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Museums in Aruba]] [[Category:2001 establishments in the Netherlands Antilles]] [[Category:Museums established in 2001]] {{museum-stub}} {{Aruba-stub}}

{{Hatnote|This article is about newsletters in general. For the Northern Irish newspaper, see [[The News Letter]]. For the [[Johns Hopkins University]] student newspaper, see [[The Johns Hopkins News-Letter]].}} {{Wiktionary}} A '''newsletter''' is a printed report containing news ([[Information|information]]) of the activities of a [[business]] ([[Legal name (business)|legal name]]; [[subscription business model]]) or an [[organization]] ([[institutions]], [[societies]], [[Trade association|associations]]) that is sent by [[mail]] regularly to all its members, customers, employees or people, who are interested in. Newsletters generally contain one main topic of interest to its recipients. A newsletter may be considered [[grey literature]]. E-newsletters are delivered electronically via [[e-mail]] and can be viewed as [[spamming]] if [[Email marketing|e-mail marketing]] is sent unsolicited.<ref>[http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/newsletter newsletter] ([[British English]], [[American English]]): [[Cambridge English Dictionary]], retrieved on 2017-05-18.</ref><ref>[https://www.britannica.com/topic/publishing/Newspaper-publishing#ref398173 Commercial newsletters in continental Europe], article of [[Encyclopedia Britannica]], retrieved on 2018-05-14.</ref><ref>Kathleen L. Endres, NEWSLETTERS, NEWSPAPERS, PAMPHLETS in: Journalism and Mass Communication, Volume 1, [[EOLSS]] publishers/[[UNESCO]], Oxford 2009, {{ISBN|978-1-905839-71-1}}, [https://books.google.de/books?id=z03DDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA90&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 90-104]</ref><ref>[https://www.washington.edu/marketing/files/2012/10/ContentGuide.pdf Best Practices for Developing Effective E-Newsletter Content] on the website of the [[University of Washington]], retrieved on 2018-05-09.</ref>
